{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Sex and the law}} {{Violence against women}} '''Forced prostitution''', also known as '''involuntary prostitution''', is [[prostitution]] or [[sexual slavery]] that takes place as a result of [[coercion]] by a third party. The terms "forced prostitution" or "enforced prostitution" appear in international and humanitarian conventions such as [[Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court]]<ref>Article 7: [[Crime against humanity]]</ref> but have been insufficiently understood and inconsistently applied. "Forced prostitution" refers to conditions of control over a person who is coerced by another to engage in sexual activity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unhchr.ch/huridocda/huridoca.nsf/0/3d25270b5fa3ea998025665f0032f220?OpenDocument |title=Report of the Special Rapporteur on systematic rape |publisher=Unhchr.ch |date= |accessdate=7 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112211407/http://www.unhchr.ch/huridocda/huridoca.nsf/0/3d25270b5fa3ea998025665f0032f220?OpenDocument |archivedate=12 January 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Forced prostitution is a crime against the person because of the violation of the victim's rights of movement through coercion and because of their commercial exploitation.
==Legal situation== '''Forced prostitution''' is illegal under [[customary law]] in all countries.<ref name="Bantekas 2003 6">{{cite book |title= International Criminal Law|edition=2d|last= Bantekas |first= Ilias |author2=Susan Nash |year= 2003|publisher=Routledge |location= Cavendish |isbn= 978-1859417768 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=MyP4tSaMA_IC|page=6}}</ref> This is different from voluntary prostitution which may have a different legal status in different countries, which range from being fully illegal and [[punishable by death]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/iran.htm|title=Iran - Facts on Trafficking and Prostitution|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008164248/http://www.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/iran.htm|archivedate=8 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> to being legal and regulated as an occupation.
While the legality of adult prostitution varies between jurisdictions, the [[prostitution of children]] is illegal nearly everywhere in the world.
In 1949, the [[UN General Assembly]] adopted the [[Convention for the Suppression of the Traffic in Persons and of the Exploitation of the Prostitution of Others]]. This Convention supersedes a number of earlier conventions that covered some aspects of forced prostitution, and also deals with other aspects of prostitution. It penalises the procurement and enticement to prostitution as well as the maintenance of [[brothels]].<ref name="Bantekas 2003 6"/> As at December 2013, the Convention has only been ratified by 82 countries.<ref name=ratifications>{{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=VII-11-a&chapter=7&lang=en |title=UNTC |publisher= |accessdate=25 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907020434/https://treaties.un.org/pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=VII-11-a&chapter=7&lang=en |archivedate=7 September 2015 |df= }}</ref> One of the main reasons it has not been ratified by many countries is because it 'voluntary' is broadly defined in countries with a legal sex industry.<ref name="Bantekas 2003 6"/> For example, in countries such as [[Germany]],<ref name="economist-prostitution2004" /> [[the Netherlands]],<ref name="economist-prostitution2004" /> [[New Zealand]],<ref name="Economist-prostitution-2008">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=E1_TNVTGVRN|title=Policing prostitution: The oldest conundrum|publisher=The Economist|date=30 October 2008|accessdate=11 January 2010}} {{Subscription}}</ref> [[Greece]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18368.htm|title=Greece|work=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> and [[Turkey]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2013/01/24/world/middleeast/24iht-m24-turkey-brothel.html|title=Turkey Cracks Down on Legal Brothels|first=Susanne|last=Güsten|date=23 January 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=11 December 2015}}</ref> and other countries some forms of prostitution and pimping are legal and regulated as professional occupations.
==Child prostitution== {{Main| Child prostitution}} Child prostitution is considered inherently non-consensual and exploitative, as children, because of their age, are not legally able to consent. In most countries child prostitution is illegal irrespective of the child reaching a lower statutory [[age of consent]].
State parties to the [[Optional Protocol on the Sale of Children, Child Prostitution and Child Pornography]] are required to prohibit child prostitution. The Protocol defines a child as any human being under the age of 18, "unless an earlier [[age of majority]] is recognized by a country's law". The Protocol entered into force on 18 January 2002,<ref name=Protocol2>{{cite web|title=Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child on the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography|work=United Nations Treaty Collection|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=IV-11-c&chapter=4&lang=en|accessdate=15 December 2013}}</ref> and as of December 2013, 166 states are party to the Protocol and another 10 states have signed but not yet ratified it.<ref name=Protocol2/>
The [[Worst Forms of Child Labour Convention, 1999]] (Convention No 104) of the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) provides that the ''use, procuring or offering of a child for prostitution'' is one of the ''worst forms of [[child labor]]''. This [[Treaty|convention]], adopted in 1999, provides that countries that had ratified it must eliminate the practice urgently. It enjoys the fastest pace of ratifications in the ILO's history since 1919.
In the United States, the [[Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000]] classifies any "commercial sex act [which] is induced by force, fraud, or coercion, or in which the person induced to perform such act has not attained 18 years of age" to be a "Severe Form of Trafficking in Persons".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/tip/laws/61124.htm|title=Victims of Trafficking and Violence Protection Act of 2000|publisher=US State Department|accessdate=17 February 2010|date=28 October 2000}}</ref>
In many countries, especially poorer countries, child prostitution remains a very serious problem, and numerous tourists from the [[Western World]] travel to these countries to engage in [[child sex tourism]]. [[Child prostitution in Thailand|Thailand]], [[Cambodia]], [[India]], [[Brazil]] and [[Child prostitution in Mexico|Mexico]] have been identified as leading hotspots of child sexual exploitation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=38872 |title=RIGHTS-MEXICO: 16,000 Victims of Child Sexual Exploitation |author=Emilio Godoy |publisher=IPS |date=13 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326111520/http://www.ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=38872 |archivedate=26 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==Human trafficking== {{Main|Human trafficking}} {{Slavery}} Human trafficking, especially of girls and women, often leads to forced prostitution and sexual slavery. According to a report by the [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime|UNODC]], internationally, the most common destinations for victims of human trafficking are [[Thailand]], [[South Korea]], [[Japan]], [[Israel]], [[Belgium]], [[the Netherlands]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Turkey]] and the [[United States]].<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6497799.stm|title=UN highlights human trafficking|date=26 March 2007|accessdate=11 January 2010|publisher=the [[BBC]]}}</ref> The major sources of trafficked persons are Thailand, [[China]], [[Nigeria]], [[Albania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Belarus]], [[Moldova]], and [[Ukraine]].<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/>
Following the first international conference on the prevention of trafficking of women in Paris in 1885 a series of initiatives to restrict the trade of women into the sex trade were initiated. Both the [[League of Nations]] and the [[United Nations]] have addressed the issue.<ref>{{cite book |title= Global Sex|last= Altman|first=Dennis |authorlink= |year=2001 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location= |isbn= 9780226016054 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=XC0QDlW3YFAC&dq=forced+prostitution |page=114 }}</ref>
A 2010 [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]] report estimates that globally, 79% of identified victims of human trafficking were trafficked for sexual exploitation, 18% for forced labor, and 3% for other forms of exploitation. In 2011, preliminary [[European Commission]] in September 2011 similarly estimated that among human-trafficking victims, 75% were trafficked for sexual exploitation and the rest for forced labor or other forms of exploitation.<ref>''The EU Strategy towards the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings, 2012–2016'', [[European Commission]] [[Directorate-General for Migration and Home Affairs]].</ref>
Due to the illegal nature of prostitution and the different methodologies used in separating forced prostitution from voluntary prostitution, the extent of this phenomenon is difficult to estimate accurately. According to a 2008 report by the [[U.S. Department of State]]: "Annually, according to U.S. Government-sponsored research completed in 2006, 600,000 to 800,000 people are trafficked across national borders, which does not include millions trafficked within their own countries. Approximately 80% of transnational victims are women and girls and up to 50% are minors, and the majority of transnational victims are trafficked into commercial sexual exploitation."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2005/46606.htm|title=Trafficking in Persons Report, I. Introduction|accessdate=30 January 2010|date= 3 June 2005}}</ref> A 2014 [[European Commission]] report found that from 2010 to 2013, a total of 30,146 people were registered as victims of human trafficking in the 28 [[member states of the European Union]]; of these, 69% were victims of sexual exploitation.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29660126 Trafficking harms 30,000 in EU - most in sex trade], BBC News (October 17, 2014).</ref>
In 2004, ''[[The Economist]]'' claimed that only a small proportion of prostitutes were explicitly trafficked against their will.<ref name="economist-prostitution2004">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/3151258|title=Prostitution: Sex is their business|date=2 September 2004|accessdate=15 December 2009|publisher=The Economist}} {{Subscription}}</ref>
[[Elizabeth Pisani]] protested against the perceived hysteria around human trafficking preceding sport events like the Super Bowl or World Cup of Soccer.<ref name="wisdomOfWhores-traffick">{{cite book|last1=Pisani|first1=Elizabeth|authorlink=Elizabeth Pisani|title=The Wisdom of Whores: Bureaucrats, Brothels and the Business of AIDS|pages=213–214|url=http://www.wisdomofwhores.com/|publisher=Granta Books|isbn=978-1-84708-076-9|year=2009}}</ref>
The [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children]] (also referred to as the Palermo Protocol) is a [[Protocol (diplomacy)|protocol]] to the United Nations [[Convention against Transnational Organized Crime]] and defines human trafficking as the "recruitment, transportation, transfer, harbouring or receipt of persons, by means of the threat or use of force or other forms of coercion, of abduction, of fraud, of deception, of the abuse of power or of a position of vulnerability or of the giving or receiving of payments or benefits to achieve the consent of a person having control over another person, for the purpose of exploitation."<ref>[http://www.unodc.org/documents/treaties/UNTOC/Publications/TOC%20Convention/TOCebook-e.pdf "United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime"], Annex II, Section I, Article 3 (pg. 42). Retrieved on 21 September 2009.</ref> For this reason, threat, coercion, or use of force is not necessary to constitute trafficking, the exploitation of an existing vulnerability{{snd}}such as economic vulnerability or sexual vulnerability{{snd}}is sufficient. [[Sigma Huda]], UN special reporter on trafficking in persons, observed that "For the most part, prostitution as actually practiced in the world usually does satisfy the elements of trafficking."<ref>{{cite web |title=Prostitution and Human Trafficking: Tackling Demand <!--The Criminal Justice and Immigration Bill:A Briefing from CARE--> |url=http://chaste.org.uk/public_documents/CJI_Briefing_Doc_CARE_CHASTE_001.pdf |accessdate=19 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305202011/http://www.chaste.org.uk/public_documents/CJI_Briefing_Doc_CARE_CHASTE_001.pdf |archivedate=5 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissuesmagazine.com/july08/july2008_5.php|title="It's Not TV, Its Sexploitation" Protest Against Home Box Office|author=Norma Ramos|publisher=On the Issues Magazine|date=Summer 2008|accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref> However [[Save the Children]] see explicit trafficking and prostitution as different issues: "The issue [human trafficking] however, gets mired in controversy and confusion when prostitution too is considered as a violation of the basic human rights of both adult women and minors, and equal to sexual exploitation per se. From this standpoint then, trafficking and prostitution become conflated with each other".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.savethechildren.net/nepal/key_issues/traffdefinition.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808002851/http://www.savethechildren.net/nepal/key_issues/traffdefinition.html |archivedate=8 August 2007 |title=Definition of Trafficking |publisher=Save the Children |accessdate=11 January 2010}}</ref>
==Voluntary vs involuntary prostitution== With regard to prostitution, three worldviews exist: ''abolitionism'' (where the prostitute is considered a victim), ''regulation'' (where the prostitute is considered a worker) and ''prohibitionism'' (where the prostitute is considered a criminal). Currently all these views are represented in some Western country.
For the proponents of the abolitionist view, prostitution is always a coercive practice, and the prostitute is seen as a victim. They argue that most prostitutes are forced into the practice, either directly, by [[pimps]] and [[human trafficking|traffickers]], indirectly through [[poverty]], [[drug addiction]] and other personal problems, or, as it has been argued in recent decades by [[radical feminists]] such as [[Andrea Dworkin]], [[Melissa Farley]] and [[Catharine MacKinnon]], merely by [[patriarchal]] social structures and power relations between men and women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nostatusquo.com/ACLU/dworkin/MichLawJourI.html|title=Prostitution and Male Supremacy|year=1993}}</ref> William D. Angel finds that "most" prostitutes have been forced into the occupation through poverty, lack of education and employment possibilities.<ref>{{cite book |title= The International Law of Youth Rights |last= Angel |first= William D. |year= 1995 |publisher=Martinus Nijhoff |location= |isbn= 9780792333210 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=3kT3fTMoggIC&vq=forced+prostitution&dq=involuntary+prostitution |page=897}}</ref> [[Kathleen Barry]] argues that there should be no distinction between "free" and "coerced", "voluntary" and "involuntary" prostitution, "since any form of prostitution is a human rights violation, an affront to womanhood that cannot be considered dignified labour".<ref name="Lim 1998 14">{{cite book |title= The Sex Sector: The Economic and Social Bases of Prostitution in Southeast Asia |last= Lim |first= Lean |year= 1998 |publisher=International Labour Office |location= |isbn= 9789221095224 |page=14 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=VFNKZbL1jWwC&vq=barry&dq=%22involuntary+prostitution%22+definition}}</ref> France's [[The Greens (France)|Green Party]] argues: "The concept of "free choice" of the prostitute is indeed relative, in a society where gender inequality is institutionalized".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lesverts.fr/spip.php?article120|title=Prostitution : les Verts opposés à la réouverture des maisons closes}}</ref> The proponents of the abolitionist view hold that prostitution is a practice which ultimately leads to the mental, emotional and physical destruction of the women who engage in it, and, as such, it should be abolished. As a result of such views on prostitution, [[Sweden]],<ref name="Economist-prostitution-2008" /> [[Norway]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7806760.stm|title=New Norway law bans buying of sex|date=1 January 2009|accessdate=19 January 2010|publisher=BBC}}</ref> and [[Iceland]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jafnretti.is/jafnretti/?D10cID=ReadNews&ID=523|title=A new law makes purchase of sex illegal in Iceland|date=21 April 2009|accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref> have enacted laws which criminalize the clients of the prostitutes, but not the prostitutes themselves.
In contrast to the abolitionist view, those who are in favour of legalization do not consider the women who practice prostitution as victims, but as independent adult women who had made a choice which should be respected. Mariska Majoor, former prostitute and founder of the [[Prostitution Information Center]], from [[Amsterdam]], holds that: "In our [sex workers'] eyes it's a profession, a way of making money; it's important that we are realistic about this ... Prostitution is not bad; it's only bad if done against one's will. Most women make this decision themselves."<ref name="allow">Allow ''Women to Sell Their Bodies to Earn a Living'', Monitor (Uganda), Apr. 24, 2006.</ref> According to proponents of regulation, prostitution should be considered a legitimate activity, which must be recognized and regulated, in order to protect the workers' rights and to prevent abuse. The prostitutes are treated as [[sex workers]] who enjoy benefits similar to other [[Job (role)|occupations]]. The [[World Charter for Prostitutes Rights]] (1985), drafted by the [[International Committee for Prostitutes' Rights]], calls for the decriminalisation of "all aspects of adult prostitution resulting from individual decision".<ref name="Lim 1998 14"/> Since the mid-1970s, sex workers across the world have organised, demanding the [[decriminalisation]] of [[prostitution]], equal protection under the law, improved working conditions, the right to pay [[taxes]], travel and receive [[social benefits]] such as [[pension]]s.<ref name="hiholv1i6">{{cite news|author=Amalia Cabezos|title=Hookers in the House of the Lord|publisher=Santa Monica Mirror|date=28 July – 4 August 1999|url=http://www.smmirror.com/Volume1/issue6/hooker.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20080820101422/http://www.smmirror.com/Volume1/issue6/hooker.html|archivedate=20 August 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As a result of such views on prostitution, countries such as [[Germany]],<ref name="economist-prostitution2004" /> the [[Netherlands]]<ref name="Economist-prostitution-2008" /> and [[New Zealand]]<ref name="Economist-prostitution-2008" /> have fully legalized prostitution. Prostitution is considered a job like any other, and pimps are seen as businessmen.
In its understanding of the distinction between [[sex work]] and forced prostitution,<ref>{{cite book |title= The Sex Sector: The Economic and Social Bases of Prostitution in Southeast Asia |last= Lim |first= Lean |year= 1998 |publisher=International Labour Office |location= |isbn=978-9221095224 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=VFNKZbL1jWwC&vq=barry&dq=%22involuntary+prostitution%22+definition |page=39}}</ref> the [[Open Society Foundations]] organization states: "sex work is done by consenting adults, where the act of selling or buying sexual services is not a violation of human rights".<ref name="Open">{{cite web|title=Understanding Sex Work in an Open Society|url=http://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/explainers/understanding-sex-work-open-society|work=Open Society Foundations|publisher=Open Society Foundations|accessdate=4 January 2014|date=June 2013}}</ref>
==Legal discrimination== Sexual [[discrimination]] happens to those who work both in [[sex work]] and forced prostitution. Historically, crimes involving [[violence against women]] and having to do with prostitution and sex work have been taken less seriously by the law. Although acts such as the [[Violence Against Women Act]] have been passed to take steps toward preventing such violence, there is still sexism rooted in the way that the legal system approaches these cases. Gender based violence is a serious form of discrimination that has slipped through many cracks in the legal system of the United States.<ref>Neuwirth, Jessica. ''Equal Means Equal''. p. 68.</ref> These efforts have fallen short due to the fact that there is no constitutional protection for women against discrimination.
There is often no evidence, according to police, that when men are arrested for soliciting a prostitute that it is a gender based crime. However, there are large discrepancies between the arrests of prostitutes and the arrests of men caught in the act. While 70% of prostitution related arrests are of woman prostitutes, only 10% of related arrests are men/customers.<ref>[http://www.bayswan.org/stats.html "PENet: Prostitution Issues: Statistics"]. ''www.bayswan.org''. Retrieved 7 November 2016.</ref> Regardless if the girl or woman is either underage or forced into the exchange, she is still often arrested and victim blamed instead of being offered resources. The men who are charged with engaging in these illegal acts with woman who are prostitutes are able to pay for the exchange and therefore are usually able to pay for their release while the woman may not be able to. This generates a cycle of violence against women, as the situation’s outcome favors the man. In one case, a nineteen-year-old woman in Oklahoma was charged with offering to engage in prostitution when the woman was known to have previously been a victim of human sex trafficking.<ref name="OSCN Case Details">[http://www.oscn.net/dockets/GetCaseInformation.aspx?db=oklahoma&number=CF-2015-2310&cmid=3247403 "OSCN Case Details"]. ''www.oscn.net''. Retrieved 5 November 2016.</ref> She is an example of how the criminalization of prostitution often leads to women being arrested multiple times due to the fact that they are often punished or arrested even when the victim of a situation.<ref name="OSCN Case Details"/> Young women and girls have a much higher likelihood of getting arrested for prostitution than boys in general, and woman victims of human trafficking often end up being arrested upon multiple occasions, being registered as a sex offender, and being institutionalized.The lack of rehabilitation given to women after experiences with human [[sex trafficking]] contributes to the cycles of arrests that most woman who engage in prostitution face.
The ERA or [[Equal Rights Amendment]] is a proposed amendment to the [[United States Constitution|U.S Constitution]] that has not yet been ratified. It would guarantee that equal rights could not be denied under the law on account of sex.<ref>[http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/ "ERA: Home"]. ''www.equalrightsamendment.org''. Retrieved 7 November 2016.</ref> With this amendment in place, it would allow for sex workers and victims of human sex trafficking to have legal leverage when it comes to the discrepancies in how men and women (customers and prostitutes) are prosecuted. This is due to the fact that there would be legal grounds to argue the unequal legal treatment on account of sex, which is not currently outlawed by the U.S constitution. Although there are other acts and laws that protect against discrimination based on a variety of categories and identities, they are often not substantial enough, provide loopholes, and do not offer adequate protection.<ref>[http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/faq.htm#q10 "ERA: FAQ"]. ''www.equalrightsamendment.org''. Retrieved 7 December 2016.</ref> This connects to [[liberal feminism]] and the more individualistic approach that comes with this theory. Liberal feminists believe that there should be equality between the sexes and this should be gained through equal legal rights, equal education, and women having "greater self value as individuals".<ref>Wendell, Susan (1987). ''A (Qualified) Defense of Liberal Feminism''. Hypatia. pp. 65–66.</ref> This theory focuses on equality at a more individual level as supposed to rethinking legal systems themselves or systems of gender, just as the ERA works for the equality of sexes within an existing system.
==Global situation==
===Europe=== In Europe, since the fall of the [[Iron Curtain]], the former Eastern bloc countries such as Albania, Moldova, Bulgaria, [[Russia]], Belarus and Ukraine have been identified as the major source countries for trafficking of women and children.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Loncle |first1=Francis |title=Eastern Europe Exports Flesh to the EU |url=http://web.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/ukraine/eeeu.htm |publisher=[[Le Monde diplomatique]] |accessdate=May 18, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020522024656/http://www.uri.edu/artsci/wms/hughes/ukraine/eeeu.htm |archivedate=22 May 2002 |date=December 2001 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vn.vladnews.ru/Arch/2000/ISS228/text/upd28-1.html |title=Local women fall prey to sex slavery abroad |publisher= |accessdate=29 September 2016 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703205719/http://vn.vladnews.ru/Arch/2000/ISS228/text/upd28-1.html |archivedate=3 July 2009 |df= }}</ref> Young women and girls are often lured to wealthier countries by the promises of money and work and then reduced to sexual slavery.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Deshpande|first1=Neha A|last2=Nour|first2=Nawal M|title=Sex Trafficking of Women and Girls|issue=1|pmc=3651545|journal=Reviews in Obstetrics and Gynecology|volume=6|accessdate=31 March 2018|pages=e22–e27|date=2013|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3651545/|pmid=23687554}}</ref> It is estimated that two thirds of women trafficked for prostitution worldwide annually come from [[Eastern Europe]] and [[China]],<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Almost half of all women trafficked into Britains prostitution are Chinese |url=http://www.asianmirror.co.uk/node/1 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208182808/http://www.asianmirror.co.uk/node/1 |archivedate=8 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> three-quarters of whom have never worked as prostitutes before.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catwinternational.org/factbook/EUeast.php|title=Eastern Europe - Coalition Against Trafficking of Women|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228094602/http://www.catwinternational.org/factbook/EUeast.php|archivedate=28 December 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3979725.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Europe - A modern slave's brutal odyssey|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> The major destinations are [[Belgium]], [[the Netherlands]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Turkey]], the [[Middle East]] ([[Israel]], the [[United Arab Emirates]]), [[Asia]], Russia and the United States.<ref>[http://www.tiraspoltimes.com/node/653 Moldova: Lower prices behind sex slavery boom and child prostitution] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501093606/http://www.tiraspoltimes.com/node/653 |date=1 May 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asiapacificms.com/articles/russian_mafia/|title=The Russian Mafia in Asia|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref>
===Americas===
[[File:LuckyLucianoSmaller.jpeg|thumb|upright| Mobster [[Lucky Luciano|Charles "Lucky" Luciano]] was convicted of compulsory prostitution and running a prostitution racket in the USA in 1936 ]]
{{See also |Sex trafficking in the United States|Female homicides in Ciudad Juárez}} In Mexico, many criminal organisations lure, and capture women and use them in brothels. Once the women become useless to the organisations, they are often killed. Often, the criminal organisations focus on poor, unemployed girls, and lure them via job offerings (regular jobs), done via billboards and posters, placed on the streets. In some cities, like [[Ciudad Juárez]], there is a high degree of corruption in all levels on the social ladder (police, courts, ...) which makes it more difficult to combat this criminal activity. Hotels where women are kept and which are known by the police are often also not raided/closed down by police. Nor are the job offerings actively investigated.<ref>Gustavo Delarosa Hickerson on corruption in Ciudad Juárez</ref> Some NGO's such as [[Nuestras Hijas de Regreso a Casa A.C.]] are trying to fight back, often without much success.
In the US, in 2002, the US [[Department of State]] repeated an earlier [[CIA]] estimate that each year, about 50,000 women and children are brought against their will to the United States for sexual exploitation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.now.org/nnt/summer-2000/slavery.html|title=Worldwide Tragedy: U.S. Not Immune to Sexual Slavery|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080929051015/http://www.now.org/nnt/summer-2000/slavery.html|archivedate=29 September 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/tip/rls/tiprpt/2002/|title=2002 Report|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> Former [[Secretary of State]] [[Colin Powell]] said that "[h]ere and abroad, the victims of trafficking toil under inhuman conditions{{snd}}in [[brothel]]s, [[sweatshop]]s, fields and even in private homes."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usgovinfo.about.com/library/weekly/aa061202a.htm|title=Modern Slavery: People for Sale|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> In addition to internationally trafficked victims, American citizens are also forced into prostitution. According to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, "100,000 to 293,000 children are in danger of becoming sexual commodities."<ref>{{cite web |title=Human Trafficking: Sexual Trafficking |url=http://www.atg.wa.gov/HumanTrafficking/SexTrafficking.aspx |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213081628/http://www.atg.wa.gov/HumanTrafficking/SexTrafficking.aspx |archivedate=13 February 2010 }}</ref>
===Middle East=== Eastern European women are trafficked to several Middle Eastern countries, including Turkey and the United Arab Emirates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2005/08/42b5f74c-f6c2-475a-b488-20a0662664d1.html|title=Sex Traffickers Prey On Eastern Europeans|work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> Until 2004, Israel was a destination for human trafficking for the sex industry.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,129157,00.html Israel a Human Trafficking Haven] FoxNews.com</ref>
A high number of the Iraqi women fleeing the [[Iraq War]] turned to prostitution, while others were trafficked abroad, to countries like Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, and Iran.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sexual-terrorism.org/2007/07/12/sexual-slavery-on-the-rise-in-iraq/|title=sexual-terrorism.org|publisher=|accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref> In [[Syria]] alone, an estimated 50,000 [[Refugees of Iraq|Iraqi refugee]] girls and women, many of them widows, had become prostitutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/world/middle_east/article2701324.ece |title='50,000 Iraqi refugees' forced into prostitution |work=The Independent |accessdate=25 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708215548/http://news.independent.co.uk/world/middle_east/article2701324.ece |archivedate=8 July 2008 |df= }}</ref> Cheap Iraqi prostitutes helped to make Syria a popular destination for sex tourists before the [[Syrian Civil War]]. The clients come from wealthier countries in the Middle East<ref name="radionetherlands.nl">{{cite web|url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/iraq070824|title=Iraqi refugees forced into prostitution|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081101164711/http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/iraq070824|archivedate=1 November 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> High prices are offered for virgins.<ref name="radionetherlands.nl"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/29/world/middleeast/29syria.html?ex=1338177600&en=8caf56b484d2ebb9&ei=5124&partner=digg&exprod=digg|title=Desperate Iraqi Refugees Turn to Sex Trade in Syria|author=Katherine Zoepfmay|date=29 May 2007|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=27 February 2016}}</ref>
===Asia=== In Asia, [[Human trafficking in Japan|Japan is the major destination country for trafficked women]], especially from the [[Philippines]] and Thailand. The US State Department has rated Japan as either a ‘Tier 2’ or a ‘Tier 2 Watchlist’ country every year since 2001, in its annual ''Trafficking in Persons'' reports. Both these ratings implied that Japan was (to a greater or lesser extent) not fully compliant with minimum standards for the elimination of human trafficking trade.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Japan 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271213.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=31 March 2018}}</ref> As of 2009, an estimated 200,000 to 400,000 people are trafficked through [[Southeast Asia]], much of it for prostitution.<ref>''Far Eastern Economic Review'': "Costs Of Human Trafficking In Southeast Asia." Janis Foo, April 2009.</ref> It is common that [[Thai people|Thai]] women are lured to Japan and sold to [[Yakuza]]-controlled brothels where they are forced to work off their price.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070312143055/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/search/page.arcview.php?clid=3&id=126551&date=2006-01-23 "Woman's Dying Wish: to punish traffickers who ruined her life"] ''The Nation'', 23 January 2006</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/1993/thailand/|title=A modern form of slavery: Trafficking of Burmese Women and Girls into Brothels in Thailand|publisher=}}</ref> Further in Japan, prejudice and the absence of anti-discrimination acts often drive a [[transwoman]] into forced prostitution.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} In Cambodia at least a quarter of the 20,000 people working as prostitutes are children with some being as young as 5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.somaly.org|title=Somaly Mam Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> By the late 1990s, [[UNICEF]] estimated that there are 60,000 [[child prostitutes]] in the Philippines, describing [[Angeles, Philippines|Angeles City]] brothels as "notorious" for offering sex with children.<ref name="bbc-action-against-sex-tourists">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/politics97/news/08/0830/phil.shtml|title=Britain to Take Action Against Sex Tourists|publisher=BBC|year=1997|accessdate=10 January 2010}}</ref>
For the last decade it has been estimated that 6,000 - 7,000 girls are trafficked out of Nepal each year. But these numbers have recently risen substantially. Current numbers for girls trafficked out of the country are now 10,000 to 15,000 yearly. This is compounded as the US Central Intelligence Agency states that most trafficked girls are currently worth, in their span as a sex-worker, approx $250,000 (USD) on the sex-trades market.<ref>[http://womennewsnetwork.net/2008/12/05/lostdaughternepal808/ "Lost Daughters - An Ongoing Tragedy in Nepal,"] Women News Network - WNN, 5 December 2008</ref>
====North Korea==== {{Main|Prostitution in North Korea}}
The North Korean state engages in forced prostitution. Girls as young as 14 years old are drafted to work in the ''[[kippŭmjo]]''. Not all ''kippŭmjo'' work as prostitutes; the source used is unclear as to whether only adult women are assigned to prostitution, or whether there is [[prostitution of children]]. Other ''kippŭmjo'' activities are massaging and half-naked singing and dancing. According to the same source from April 2005, "60 to 70% of [[North Korean defectors#In China|[North Korean] defectors {{bracket|in the People's Republic of China}}]] are women, 70 to 80% of whom are victims of human trafficking." North Korean authorities severely punish or even kill repatriated prostitutes and kill their Chinese-fathered children, born and unborn alike.<ref name=jeongjs>"[http://www.awomansvoice.org/nl1-2004-2.html Intervention Agenda Item 12: Elimination of Violence Against Women] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306003144/http://www.awomansvoice.org/nl1-2004-2.html |date=6 March 2012 }}" at the [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights]] in April 2004; speaker: Ji Sun JEONG for ''A Woman's Voice International''</ref>
==History== Forced prostitution has existed throughout history.
===Nazi Germany=== {{Main|German military brothels in World War II|German camp brothels in World War II}}
[[German military brothels in World War II|German military brothels]] were set up by the [[Third Reich]] during [[World War II]] throughout much of occupied Europe for the use of [[Wehrmacht]] and [[SS]] soldiers.<ref name="Herbermann" /> These brothels were generally new creations, but in the West, they were sometimes set up using existing [[brothel]]s as well as many other buildings. Until 1942, there were around 500 military brothels of this kind in [[German-occupied Europe]].<ref name="Sander">Helge Sander, Barbara Johr (Hrsg.), ''Befreier und Befreite - Krieg - Vergewaltigung - Kinder'', Frankfurt a.M. 2005</ref> Often operating in confiscated hotels and guarded by the [[Wehrmacht]], these facilities used to serve travelling soldiers and those withdrawn from the front.<ref name="Yudkin">{{en icon}} {{cite book |editor=Leon Yudkin |title=Hebrew Literature in the Wake of the Holocaust |year=1993 |publisher=[[Fairleigh Dickinson University]] Press |isbn=978-0-8386-3499-8 |pages=13–32 |chapter=Narrative Perspectives on Holocaust Literature}}</ref><ref name="Lenten">{{en icon}} {{cite book |last=Lenten |first=Ronit |title=Israel and the Daughters of the Shoah: Reoccupying the Territories of Silence |year=2000 |publisher=Berghahn Books |isbn=978-1-57181-775-4 |pages=33–34}}</ref> According to records, at least 34,140 European women were forced to serve as prostitutes during the German occupation of their own countries along with female prisoners of [[German camp brothels in World War II|concentration camp brothels]].<ref name="Herbermann">{{cite book |author1=Nanda Herbermann |author2=Hester Baer |author3=Elizabeth Roberts Baer | title =The Blessed Abyss: Inmate #6582 in Ravensbruck Concentration Camp for Women | year =2000 | pages =33–34 | publisher =[[Wayne State University]] Press | location =Detroit | isbn=978-0-8143-2920-7 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=3JM3AdnmE18C&pg=PA34&dq=%22it+is+impossible+to+speak+of+free+will+when+considering+the+circumstances%22#v=onepage&q=%22it%20is%20impossible%20to%20speak%20of%20free%20will%20when%20considering%20the%20circumstances%22&f=false | format =[[Google Books]] | accessdate =12 January 2011}} {{en icon}}</ref> In many cases in Eastern Europe, the women involved were kidnapped on the streets of occupied cities during German military and police [[Roundup (history)|round up]]s called ''łapanka'' or ''rafle''.<ref name="Yudkin"/><ref name="Lenten"/>
In [[World War II]], [[Nazi Germany]] established brothels in the concentration camps (''[[Lagerbordell]]'') to create an incentive for prisoners to collaborate, although these institutions were used mostly by [[Kapo (concentration camp)|Kapos]], "prisoner functionaries" and the criminal element, because regular inmates, penniless and emaciated, were usually too debilitated and wary of exposure to [[Schutzstaffel]] (SS) schemes. In the end, the camp brothels did not produce any noticeable increase in the prisoners' work productivity levels, but instead, created a market for coupons among the camp VIPs.<ref name="wollheim">[http://www.wollheim-memorial.de/en/lagerbordell_en "Camp Brothel".] ''Wollheim Memorial''. Accessed 30 June 2011.</ref> The women forced into these brothels came mainly from the [[Ravensbrück concentration camp]],<ref name=derspiegel2007>{{Cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/nazi-sex-slaves-new-exhibition-documents-forced-prostitution-in-concentration-camps-a-459704.html|title=Nazi Sex Slaves: New Exhibition Documents Forced Prostitution in Concentration Camps - SPIEGEL ONLINE - International|first=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg|last=Germany|newspaper=Spiegel Online|date=2007-01-15}}</ref> except for [[Auschwitz]], which employed its own prisoners.<ref name="Herbermann" /> In combination with the [[German military brothels in World War II]], it is estimated that at least 34,140 female inmates were forced into sexual slavery during the [[Third Reich]].<ref name="Herbermann"/>
===Comfort women=== [[File:Chinese girl from one of the Japanese Army's 'comfort battalions'.jpg|thumb|[[Rangoon]], [[Myanmar|Burma]]. 8 August 1945. A young [[Chinese diaspora|ethnic Chinese]] woman from one of the [[Imperial Japanese Army]]'s "comfort battalions" is interviewed by an [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] officer.]] {{Main|Comfort women}} Comfort women is a [[euphemism]] for women working in military [[brothel]]s, especially by the [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] military during [[World War II]].<ref>{{Citation |url=http://japanfocus.org/products/details/2373 |title=Japan's 'Comfort Women': It's time for the truth (in the ordinary, everyday sense of the word) |author=Tessa Morris-Suzuki |date=8 March 2007 |accessdate=15 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109083324/http://japanfocus.org/products/details/2373 |archivedate=9 January 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="definition">{{Harvnb|WCCW|2004}}.</ref>
Around 200,000 are typically estimated to have been involved, with estimates as low as 20,000 from some Japanese scholars<ref name="AWF_CW">{{Harvnb|Asian Women'sFund|p=10|Ref=AWF-CW}}</ref> and estimates of up to 410,000 from some Chinese scholars,<ref>{{Harvnb|Rose|2005|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=W2nU1Xu0XdkC&pg=PA88 88]}}</ref> but the disagreement about exact numbers is still being researched and debated. Historians and researchers have stated that the majority were from [[Korea]], [[China]], [[Japan]] and [[Philippines]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://womenshistory.about.com/od/warwwii/a/comfort_women.htm|title=Women and World War II - Comfort Women|author=Jone Johnson Lewis|work=About.com Education|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> but women from [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]], [[Malaysia]], [[Taiwan]], [[Indonesia]], [[East Timor]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etan.org/issues/ww2.htm|title=Japanese Military Sexual Slavery in East Timor|publisher=|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> and other [[Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere|Japanese-occupied territories]] were also used in "comfort stations". Stations were located in [[Japan]], [[China]], the [[Philippines]], [[Indonesia]], then [[British Malaya|Malaya]], [[Thailand]], then [[Burma]], then [[New Guinea]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Macau]], and what was then [[French Indochina]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Reuters|2007-03-05}}.</ref>
Young women from countries under Japanese Imperial control were reportedly abducted from their homes. In some cases, women were also recruited with offers to work in the military.<ref>{{Harvnb|Yoshimi|2000|pp=100–101, 105–106, 110–111}};<br />{{Harvnb|Fackler 2007-03-06|Ref=CITEREFNY Times2007-03-06}};<br />{{Harvnb|BBC 2007-03-02}};<br />{{Harvnb|BBC 2007-03-08}}.</ref> It has been documented that the Japanese military itself recruited women by force.<ref>{{Harvnb|van Buitenlandse zaken|1994|pp=6–9, 11, 13–14}}</ref> However, Japanese historian [[Ikuhiko Hata]] stated that there was no organized forced recruitment of comfort women by the Japanese government or military.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://hassin.sejp.net/Hata-Ianfu_text.pdf |title=NO ORGANIZED OR FORCED RECRUITMENT: MISCONCEPTIONS ABOUT COMFORT WOMEN AND THE JAPANESE MILITARY |author=Hata Ikuhiko |publisher=hassin.sejp.net |format=PDF |accessdate=15 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080904020445/http://hassin.sejp.net/Hata-Ianfu_text.pdf |archivedate=4 September 2008 |df= }} (First published in Shokun May 2007 issue in Japanese. Translated by Society for the Dissemination of Historical Fact).</ref>
The number and nature of comfort women servicing the Japanese military during World War II is still being actively debated, and the matter is still highly political in both Japan and the rest of the [[Far East|Far East Asia]].<ref>According to journalist Satoshi Ikeuchi: "Even though the forcible recruitment of women was not systematically implemented, the (Japanese) government should acknowledge its moral responsibility if any single woman victimized by the private operators through fraud, exploitation, violence or other acts of intimidation comes forward to tell her story. The government should do so because the military gave consent to set up brothels for soldiers and had responsibility for overseeing them.» «In this context, the issue of the so-called comfort women was invested with extreme importance as the epitome of Japanese sin from the viewpoint of some and became the focal point of contention, The excessive effort by leftists and liberals in politicizing this issue as one of the few means left to shake conservative dominance, by extending the notion of coercion to the extreme, resulted in alienating a large part of the nation. Their open intention to collude with rising tides of hostile nationalism in Korea and China also hardened the minds of many in Japan." 25 April 2007. Satoshi Ikeuchi, [http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/columns/commentary/20070425dy01.htm Overcoming postwar mind-set], Daily Yomuri Online, 25 April 2007.</ref>
Many military brothels were run by private agents and supervised by the Korean Police. Some Japanese historians, using the testimony of ex-comfort women, have argued that the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] and [[Imperial Japanese Navy|Navy]] were either directly or indirectly involved in coercing, deceiving, luring, and sometimes kidnapping young women throughout Japan's [[Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere|Asian colonies and occupied territories]].<ref name="denial">{{Harvnb|Onishi 2007-03-08|Ref=CITEREFNY Times2007-03-08}}</ref>
==Religious attitudes== {{See also|Sacred prostitution}}
===Hinduism===
In Southern [[India]] & eastern Indian state of [[Odisha]], [[devadasi]] is the practice of hierodulic prostitution, with similar customary forms such as basavi,<ref>Anti-Slavery Society. [http://anti-slaverysociety.addr.com/hieroras.htm Child Hierodulic Servitude in India and Nepal]</ref> and involves dedicating pre-pubescent and young adolescent girls from villages in a ritual marriage to a deity or a temple, who then work in the temple and function as spiritual guides, dancers, and prostitutes servicing male devotees in the temple. [[Human Rights Watch]] reports claim that devadasis are forced into this service and, at least in some cases, to practice prostitution for upper-caste members.<ref>Human Rights Watch. [http://hrw.org/campaigns/caste/presskit.htm Caste: Asia's Hidden Apartheid]</ref>
Various state governments in [[India]] enacted laws to ban this practice both prior to India's independence and more recently. They include Bombay Devdasi Act, 1934, Devdasi (Prevention of dedication) Madras Act, 1947, Karnataka Devdasi (Prohibition of dedication) Act, 1982, and Andhra Pradesh Devdasi (Prohibition of dedication) Act, 1988.<ref>United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women. [https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/cedaw/cedaw37/responses/cedaw.c.ind.q.3.add.1%20single.pdf Thirty-seventh session: 15 January – 2 February 2007]</ref> However, the tradition continues in certain regions of India, particularly the states of [[Karnataka]] and [[Andhra Pradesh]].<ref name=thehindu>{{cite news |title = `Project Combat' launched to eradicate `Devadasi' system |publisher = The Hindu |date = 30 January 2006 |url = http://www.hindu.com/2006/01/30/stories/2006013020130300.htm |accessdate = 31 January 2007 }}</ref>

{{Infobox book | name = The Foundations of Geopolitics: The Geopolitical Future of Russia | author = [[Aleksandr Dugin]] | language = [[Russian language|Russian]] | country = Russia | genre = | publisher = Arktogeja | isbn = 978-5-8592-8019-3 | title_orig = Основы геополитики (геополитическое будущее России) / Osnovy geopolitiki: Geopoliticheskoe budushchee Rossii | orig_lang_code = ru | translator = | image = FoundationsGeopolitics.jpg | caption = Russian edition cover | illustrator = | cover_artist = | series = | subject = | release_date = 1997 | english_release_date = | media_type = | pages = | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Foundations of Geopolitics: The Geopolitical Future of Russia''''' is a [[geopolitics|geopolitical]] book by [[Aleksandr Dugin]]. The book has had a large influence within the Russian military, police, and foreign policy elites<ref name="HI01">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoover.org/research/russias-new-and-frightening-ism|title=Russia’s New—and Frightening—“Ism”|last=Dunlop|first=John B.|date=July 30, 2004|work=Hoover Institution|accessdate=12 October 2017}}</ref> and it has been used as a textbook in the [[General Staff Academy (Russia)|Academy of the General Staff]] of the Russian military.<ref name="HI01"/><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/07/27/geopolitics-russia-mackinder-eurasia-heartland-dugin-ukraine-eurasianism-manifest-destiny-putin/|title=The Unlikely Origins of Russia's Manifest Destiny|website=Foreign Policy|access-date=2017-10-23}}</ref> Its publication in 1997 was well-received in Russia and powerful Russian political figures subsequently took an interest in Dugin,<ref name="Liverant">{{cite journal|last=Liverant|first=Yigal|date=Winter 2009|title=The Prophet of the New Russian Empire|journal=Azure|publisher=Shalem Center|location=Jerusalem|issue=35|issn=0793-6664|url=http://azure.org.il/include/print.php?id=483|accessdate=2015-04-06}}</ref> a Russian fascist<ref name="Umland">"Classification of Dugin as a fascist is justified, regardless of the fact that today the MGU professor frequently speaks not as a primitive ethnocentrist or biological racist. (...) By «fascist» we understand the «generic» meaning of the concept, used in comparatory research of contemporary right-wing extremism by such well-known historians-comparativists as Alexandr Galkin (Moscow), Walter Laqueur (Washington), Stanley Payne (Madison), Wolfgang Wippermann (Berlin) or Roger Griffin (Oxford)", {{cite web | url=http://inosmi.ru/politic/20120622/193954633.html | title="Евразийские" проекты Путина и Дугина – сходства и различия |trans-title=Dugin's "Eurasian" projects − similarities and differences | publisher=Geopolitika (Lithuania) | date=22 June 2012 | accessdate=31 August 2015 | author=Андреас Умланд}}</ref> and nationalist<ref name="Koposov">{{cite book|last=Koposov|first=Nikolay|title=Memory Laws, Memory Wars|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2S42DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA211&dq=Gennady+Seleznyov+dugin+-during&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjrvZXPtonXAhUFx2MKHfG9CXwQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=Gennady%20Seleznyov%20dugin%20-during&f=false|date=October 13, 2017|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781108419727|page=211}}</ref> who has developed a close relationship with Russia's Academy of the General Staff.<ref name="Lavelle">{{cite book|last=Lavelle|first=Peter|title=Uncovering Russia (excerpt: A civil society without civility)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0qQixjX1hwoC&pg=PA380&dq=Gennady+Seleznyov+dugin+-during&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjrvZXPtonXAhUFx2MKHfG9CXwQ6AEIODAD#v=onepage&q=Gennady%20Seleznyov%20dugin%20-during&f=false|year=2003|publisher=Norasco Publishing Ltd.|isbn=0972970800|pages=379–380}}</ref>
Dugin credits General [[Nikolai Klokotov]] of the Academy of the General Staff as co-author and main inspiration,<ref name="newsau">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/europe/1990s-manifesto-outlining-russias-plans-is-starting-to-come-true/news-story/343a27c71077b87668f1aa783d03032c|title=1990s Manifesto outlining Russia’s plans is starting to come true|last=Firth|first=Charles|date=March 4, 2017|work=news.com.au|accessdate=12 October 2017}}</ref> though Klokotov denies this.<ref name=":0" /> Colonel General [[Leonid Ivashov]], head of the International Department of the [[Russian Ministry of Defence]], helped draft the book.<ref name="Mankoff">{{cite book|last=Mankoff|first=Jeffrey|title=Russian Foreign Policy: The Return of Great Power Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SZWk9egC4tUC&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=Foundations+of+Geopolitics+Ivashov&source=bl&ots=PlRn_Q2zAp&sig=v2Bv7lRYy3DzFhIeGODwe1rebtY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiVitmXpevWAhUmllQKHYMODRgQ6AEIWDAJ#v=onepage&q=Foundations%20of%20Geopolitics%20Ivashov&f=false|date=October 17, 2011|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|pages=69–70}}</ref>
==Use== Klokotov stated that in the future the book would "serve as a mighty ideological foundation for preparing a new military command".<ref name="dunlop">{{cite journal|last=Dunlop|first=John|date=January 31, 2004|title=Aleksandr Dugin's Foundations of Geopolitics|journal=Demokratizatsiya: The Journal of Post-Soviet Democratization|publisher=Institute for European, Russian and Eurasian Studies (George Washington University)|volume=12|issue=1|page=41|issn=1074-6846|oclc=222569720|url=https://www2.gwu.edu/~ieresgwu/assets/docs/demokratizatsiya%20archive/GWASHU_DEMO_12_1/John%20Dunlop%20Aleksandr%20Dugin%27s%20Foundations%20of%20Geopolitics.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160607175004/https://www2.gwu.edu/~ieresgwu/assets/docs/demokratizatsiya%20archive/GWASHU_DEMO_12_1/John%20Dunlop%20Aleksandr%20Dugin's%20Foundations%20of%20Geopolitics.pdf|archive-date=7 June 2016}}</ref> Dugin has asserted that the book has been adopted as a textbook in many Russian educational institutions.<ref name="HI01"/> Former speaker of the Russian State [[Duma]], [[Gennadiy Seleznyov]], for whom Dugin was adviser on geopolitics,<ref name="toal">{{cite book|last=Toal|first=Gerard|title=Near Abroad: Putin, the West and the Contest Over Ukraine and the Caucasus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vfiSDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=Gennadiy+Seleznyov+foundations+of+geopolitics&source=bl&ots=lz80vKevIf&sig=0rZ3oGpdLsLBgu4N6tbT7l9S_ao&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiR8K6NtYnXAhVM-GMKHelXB3oQ6AEIRzAF#v=onepage&q=Gennadiy%20Seleznyov%20foundations%20of%20geopolitics&f=false|year=2017|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190253301|page=78}}</ref> has "urged that Dugin's geopolitical doctrine be made a compulsory part of the school curriculum".<ref name="dunlop"/>
==Content== In ''Foundations of Geopolitics'', Dugin calls for the influence of the United States and [[Atlanticism]] to lose its influence in [[Eurasia]] and for Russia to rebuild its influence through annexations and alliances.<ref name=":0" />
The book declares that "the battle for the world rule of [ethnic] Russians" has not ended and Russia remains "the staging area of a new anti-bourgeois, [[Anti-Americanism|anti-American revolution]]". The Eurasian Empire will be constructed "on the fundamental principle of the common enemy: the rejection of [[Atlanticism]], strategic control of the USA, and the refusal to allow [[Liberalism|liberal]] values to dominate us."<ref name="dunlop" />
Military operations play relatively little role. The textbook believes in a sophisticated program of subversion, destabilization, and disinformation spearheaded by the Russian special services. The operations should be assisted by a tough, hard-headed utilization of Russia's gas, oil, and natural resources to bully and pressure other countries.<ref name="dunlop" />
The book states that "the maximum task [of the future] is the '[[Finlandization]]' of all of Europe".<ref name="dunlop" />
In Europe: * [[Germany]] should be offered the de facto political dominance over most Protestant and Catholic states located within Central and Eastern Europe. [[Kaliningrad oblast]] could be given back to Germany. The book uses the term "Moscow–Berlin axis".<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[France]] should be encouraged to form a "Franco–German bloc" with Germany. Both countries have a "firm anti-Atlanticist tradition".<ref name="dunlop" /> * The [[United Kingdom]] should be cut off from Europe.<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Finland]] should be absorbed into Russia. Southern Finland will be combined with the [[Republic of Karelia]] and northern Finland will be "donated to [[Murmansk Oblast]]".<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Estonia]] should be given to Germany's sphere of influence.<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Latvia]] and [[Lithuania]] should be given a "special status" in the Eurasian-Russian sphere.<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Poland]] should be granted a "special status" in the Eurasian sphere.<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Romania]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], "[[Republika Srpska|Serbian Bosnia]]" and [[Greece]] – "[[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] collectivist East" – will unite with "Moscow the [[Third Rome]]" and reject the "rational-individualistic West".<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Ukraine]] should be annexed by Russia because "Ukraine as a state has no geopolitical meaning, no particular cultural import or universal significance, no geographic uniqueness, no ethnic exclusiveness, its certain territorial ambitions represents an enormous danger for all of Eurasia and, without resolving the Ukrainian problem, it is in general senseless to speak about continental politics". Ukraine should not be allowed to remain independent, unless it is [[cordon sanitaire]], which would be inadmissible.<ref name="dunlop" />
In the Middle East and Central Asia: * The book stresses the "continental Russian–Islamic alliance" which lies "at the foundation of anti-Atlanticist strategy". The alliance is based on the "traditional character of Russian and Islamic civilization". * [[Iran]] is a key ally. The book uses the term "Moscow–Tehran axis".<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Armenia]] has a special role: It will serve as a "strategic base," and it is necessary to create "the [subsidiary] axis Moscow-Erevan-Teheran". Armenians "are an Aryan people ... [like] the Iranians and the Kurds".<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Azerbaijan]] could be "split up" or given to Iran.<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] should be dismembered. [[Abkhazia]] and "United Ossetia" (which includes Georgia's [[South Ossetia]]) will be incorporated into Russia. Georgia's independent policies are unacceptable.<ref name="dunlop" /> * Russia needs to create "geopolitical shocks" within [[Turkey]]. These can be achieved by employing Kurds, Armenians and other minorities.<ref name="dunlop" /> * The book regards the Caucasus as a Russian territory, including "the eastern and northern shores of the Caspian (the territories of [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Turkmenistan]])" and Central Asia (mentioning Kazakhstan, [[Uzbekistan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]] and [[Tajikistan]]).<ref name="dunlop" />
In Asia: * [[China]], which represents a danger to Russia, "must, to the maximum degree possible, be dismantled". Dugin suggests that Russia start by taking [[Tibet]]–[[Xinjiang]]–[[Mongolia]]–[[Manchuria]] as a security belt.<ref name="HI01"/> Russia should offer China help "in a southern direction – Indochina (except Vietnam), the Philippines, Indonesia, Australia" as geopolitical compensation.<ref name="dunlop" /> * Russia should manipulate [[Politics of Japan|Japanese politics]] by offering the [[Kuril Islands]] to Japan and provoking anti-Americanism.<ref name="dunlop" /> * [[Mongolia]] should be absorbed into Eurasia-Russia.<ref name="dunlop"/>
The book emphasizes that Russia must spread Anti-Americanism everywhere: "the main 'scapegoat' will be precisely the U.S."
In the United States: * Russia should use its special services within the borders of the United States to fuel instability and separatism, for instance, provoke "Afro-American racists". Russia should "introduce geopolitical disorder into internal American activity, encouraging all kinds of separatism and ethnic, social and racial conflicts, actively supporting all dissident movements – extremist, racist, and sectarian groups, thus destabilizing internal political processes in the U.S. It would also make sense simultaneously to support [[Isolationism|isolationist]] tendencies in American politics".<ref name="dunlop" />
The Eurasian Project could be expanded to South and Central America.<ref name="dunlop" />
==Reception== [[Hoover Institution]] senior fellow [[John B. Dunlop]] stated that "the impact of this intended 'Eurasianist' textbook on key Russian elites testifies to the worrisome rise of fascist ideas and sentiments during the late Yeltsin and the Putin period".<ref name="HI01"/>
Historian [[Timothy Snyder]] wrote in ''[[The New York Review of Books]]'' that ''Foundations of Geopolitics'' is influenced by the work of [[Carl Schmitt]], a proponent of a conservative international order whose work influenced the [[Nazis]]. He also noted Dugin's key role in forwarding the ideologies of [[Eurasianism]] and [[National Bolshevism]].<ref name="snyder">{{cite web|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2014/mar/20/fascism-russia-and-ukraine/|title=Fascism, Russia, and Ukraine|last=Snyder|first=Timothy|date=20 March 2014|work=[[The New York Review of Books]]|accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref>
The book was described by ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' as "one of the most curious, impressive, and terrifying books to come out of Russia during the entire post-Soviet era", and "more sober than Dugin’s previous books, better argued, and shorn of occult references, numerology, traditionalism and other eccentric metaphysics".<ref name=":0" />
In 2017, [[news.com.au]] said that the book "reads like a to-do list for Putin's behaviour on the world stage".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/europe/1990s-manifesto-outlining-russias-plans-is-starting-to-come-true/news-story/343a27c71077b87668f1aa783d03032c|title=This is what Russian heavyweights wanted in the ‘90s|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2017-10-23}}</ref>
==See also== * ''[[The Grand Chessboard]]''
